name: Diwali
title: Festival of Lights - Deepavali
description: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is the most celebrated Hindu festival symbolizing the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. The festival spans five days, with each day having its own significance and rituals.
significance: Celebrates the return of Lord Rama to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile and his victory over the demon king Ravana.

seo.description: Complete guide to Diwali festival with rituals, stories, bhajans, aartis, recipes, and celebrations. Learn the significance of Festival of Lights.

sections.title: Welcome to Diwali
sections.content: Diwali, the festival of lights, is one of the most important Hindu festivals celebrated across India and worldwide. This five-day festival signifies the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

sections.title: Historical Significance
sections.content: Diwali has been celebrated for thousands of years and finds mention in ancient Hindu scriptures. The festival marks various historical events including Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya, Goddess Lakshmi's emergence during Samudra Manthan, and the victory of Lord Krishna over the demon Narakasura.

sections.title: Famous Stories
sections.content: The most well-known story of Diwali is the return of Lord Rama, his wife Sita, and his brother Lakshmana to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile. The people of Ayodhya lit countless oil lamps (diyas) to illuminate their path and celebrate the triumph of good over evil.

subsections.title: Lord Rama's Return
subsections.content: After defeating the demon king Ravana and rescuing Sita, Lord Rama returned to Ayodhya. The entire kingdom celebrated by lighting diyas and decorating the city. This tradition continues to this day.

subsections.title: Goddess Lakshmi's Emergence
subsections.content: During the churning of the cosmic ocean (Samudra Manthan), Goddess Lakshmi emerged from the ocean and chose Lord Vishnu as her husband. Diwali is celebrated to honor her and seek her blessings for prosperity.

sections.title: How Diwali is Celebrated
sections.content: Diwali celebrations span five days, each with its own significance and rituals. The festival begins with Dhanteras and ends with Bhai Dooj.

subsections.title: Day 1: Dhanteras
subsections.content: Dhanteras marks the beginning of Diwali celebrations. People buy gold, silver, and new utensils as it is considered auspicious. Goddess Lakshmi is worshipped for prosperity.

subsections.title: Day 2: Choti Diwali
subsections.content: Also known as Naraka Chaturdashi, this day celebrates Lord Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura. People take oil baths and decorate their homes.

subsections.title: Day 3: Main Diwali
subsections.content: The main day of Diwali celebrates Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya. People light diyas, burst fireworks, and worship Goddess Lakshmi.

subsections.title: Day 4: Govardhan Puja
subsections.content: This day celebrates Lord Krishna lifting the Govardhan Hill to protect villagers from Indra's wrath. People prepare mountain-shaped food offerings.

subsections.title: Day 5: Bhai Dooj
subsections.content: The final day celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters apply tilak on their brothers' foreheads and pray for their well-being.

sections.title: Rituals and Pooja
sections.content: Diwali pooja is performed on the main day of Diwali to seek blessings from Goddess Lakshmi and Lord Ganesha.

subsections.title: Lakshmi-Ganesha Pooja
subsections.content: The main Diwali pooja involves worshipping Goddess Lakshmi (goddess of wealth) and Lord Ganesha (remover of obstacles). The pooja is performed during the evening hours.

subsections.title: Pooja Samagri
subsections.content: Essential items for Diwali pooja include diyas, incense sticks, flowers, fruits, sweets, kumkum, haldi, and sacred water. A silver or clay idol of Goddess Lakshmi is placed on a red cloth.

sections.title: Diwali Special Foods
sections.content: Diwali is incomplete without traditional sweets and snacks. Here are some must-have Diwali delicacies:

subsections.title: Traditional Sweets
subsections.content: Popular Diwali sweets include Kaju Katli, Motichoor Ladoo, Gulab Jamun, Jalebi, Rasgulla, and Besan Laddu. These sweets are distributed among family and friends.

subsections.title: Savory Snacks
subsections.content: Savory items include Samosas, Kachoris, Mathri, Chakli, and Namkeen. These snacks are prepared in advance and stored for guests.

sections.title: Diwali Bhajans
sections.content: Devotional songs sung during Diwali to seek blessings from deities.

subsections.title: Aarti Shree Lakshmi Ji
subsections.english:
Aarti of Shree Lakshmi Ji
O Mother who resides on lotus
Beloved of Vishnu, Shree Lakshmi
Mother of the world

Your devotees have come
To your door, O Mother
Remove sorrows, give happiness
Do good for everyone, Mother
subsections.meaning: This devotional bhajan is sung to honor Goddess Lakshmi, seeking her blessings for prosperity and well-being.

sections.title: Diwali Aartis
sections.content: Traditional aartis performed during Diwali celebrations.

subsections.title: Om Jai Lakshmi Mata
subsections.english:
Om Jai Lakshmi Mata, Mother Jai Lakshmi Mata
Day and night we meditate on you, Hari Vishnu the creator
Om Jai Lakshmi Mata
subsections.meaning: The complete traditional aarti of Goddess Lakshmi, acknowledging her various forms and seeking her blessings.
